overview: How to make arrangements for your children if you divorce or separate, and how to apply for a court order if you can't agree
title: Looking after children if you divorce or separate

table.body:
A court won't let you divorce, or dissolve a civil partnership, until you can show you have made arrangements for your children, like:

- where the children will live
- when they’ll spend time with each parent
- who will pay [child maintenance](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Parents/ChildMaintenance/index.htm "child maintenance"){:rel="external"}

##If you're unable to agree

If you're unable to agree on these arrangements, you can ask the court to decide, using a court order.

If you want to do this, you first have to go to a 'mediation information and assessment meeting' with a family mediator.

This  to find out if you can reach an agreement with your partner without going to court.

Contact a [family mediation service](http://www.familymediationhelpline.co.uk/find-service.php/ "family mediation service"){:rel="external"} to arrange to go to a meeting.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You can apply for a single court order, or a number of them, depending on what you've been unable to agree on.

##Residence order

To decide where your child will live, and which parent they will live with.

You could apply for shared parenting, so the child spends time living with both parents.

##Contact order

To see the child when they live with the other parent - eg:

- at weekends
- during school holidays

##Specific issue order

To look at a specific question about how the child is being brought up - eg:

- what school they go to
- whether they should have a religious education

##Prohibited steps order

To stop the other parent from doing something without the permission of the court - eg:

- changing the child's surname
- taking the child abroad

##Parental responsibility order

To apply to have the rights and responsibilities of a parent, eg if:

- you weren't married to the mother when the child was born
- you aren't registered as the father on the birth certificate
